Johannes Brodwall wrote:

> Hi Bhavani,
> It's a little bit difficult to answer your question without knowing your
> code, but I suspect your situation is something like this:
>
> - You call java.sql.Connection.getConnection
> - When the database is down, you catch the SQLException thrown in by
> getConnection, and let the connection reference remain null.
>
> I would personally prefer to propagate the SQLException, alternatively to
> wrap it in a Subsystem-type exception.  Using null-reference as a signal for
> errors is a good way to introduce bugs.  In general, an unexpected Null
> reference is usually a Failure, not an error.  See Eric Allen's Bug Patterns
> series in IBM developerWorks for more info.  Especially "The Null Flag bug
> pattern" - http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-diag3.html
>
> This was probably not the answer you were looking for, so I will give you a
> short answer as well:  I prefer the first variant.  (If my understanding of
> the situation is correct)
>
> Sincerely,
> Johannes Brodwall
